summary: This is a joint letter from the prosecution and defense in the Ghislaine Maxwell criminal case, filed with Judge Alison J. Nathan. It outlines proposed procedures for protecting witness identities at the upcoming trial, including the use of pseudonyms, voir dire processes, jury instructions, and handling of sealed exhibits. The document reveals logistical preparations for the trial set to begin on November 29, 2021.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell, for which this procedural letter is being filed.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the Ghislaine Maxwell case, to whom this joint letter is addressed.

persons.name: Judge Garaufis
persons.context: Judge in the unrelated United States v. Raniere case, whose jury instruction regarding witness anonymity is cited as a model by the prosecution.

persons.name: MS. PENZA
persons.context: Appears in the transcript excerpt, representing the government, discussing witness list procedures and responding to the court.

persons.name: MR. AGNIFILO
persons.context: Appears in the transcript excerpt, representing the defense, objecting to the proposed jury instruction.

persons.name: Denise Parisi
persons.context: The court reporter for the transcribed proceedings included in the filing.

connections.description: MR. AGNIFILO is acting as defense counsel for Ghislaine Maxwell, objecting to procedures on her behalf.
MS. PENZA is a prosecutor representing the government in the case against Ghislaine Maxwell.
Judge Nathan is presiding over the criminal case against defendant Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: Pretrial Conference
events.description: A pretrial conference was held where Judge Nathan directed the parties to file a joint letter regarding protections for witness identities at trial.

events.title: Trial Start Date
events.description: The scheduled start date for the trial of United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: Motion for Mistrial Denied
events.description: During a proceeding, the defense moved for a mistrial, which Judge Nathan denied, opting instead to issue a curative jury instruction.

keyFacts: The prosecution and defense agreed on procedures to protect witness identities at trial, including using pseudonyms or first names only for certain alleged victims and related witnesses.
The trial for United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell was scheduled to begin on November 29, 2021.
Judge Nathan denied a defense motion for a mistrial related to witness naming issues, deciding a jury instruction would suffice.
The document references a prior case, United States v. Raniere, as a model for jury instructions on witness anonymity.
Procedures were established for handling sealed exhibits, including providing jurors with individual binders to prevent public viewing of sensitive information.
